item.title: [ROO-241] Allow user to specify "order by" on dynamic finders
item.description: Would be helpful on large resultsets that are traditionally sorted by the db before returning the resultset.
item.summary: Allow user to specify "order by" on dynamic finders

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: Some potential syntax approaches are suggested in the forum thread linked above.

I would like to see a @RooEntity parameter for an entity's default sort field(s).

I'm hooking up a Roo to a preexisting Accounts table, and the default Index view doesn't sort by anything I've been able to notice. Having an automatic sort by [lastName, firstName] or at least ID (which is the username in our case) would be better.

(Re-posted & edited from the forum thread)

I consider this essential. I can't think of any Roo-generated finders in my app that are useful if unsorted, so I will have to push-in refactor all of them just to add an order-by clause. Either a default sort field annotation or means to specify order-by fields on cmd line would be useful.

Despite more than 30 votes for this issue, there is still no version mentioned where this fix will be included. Have you planned to support this behavior in a near future ? That's a basic but really useful (and awaited) functionality in applications.
I like this feature and I wonder if it's possible to add full pagination support: ordering, of course, and starting and ending rows (or pageindex and pagesize parameters).

Perhaps new options "orderBy" and "filterClass" could be used to add a parameter to the finder methods:

finder add --finderName findEmployeesByDepartment --orderBy "userName ASC" --filterClass ~.server.domain.EmployeePagingFilter

//(annotation might be formatted something like this)
@RooEntity(finders = {

{name="findEmployeesByDepartment",orderBy="userName ASC",filterClass=EmployeePagingFilter}

})
public class Employee {
...
}

Filters would allow paging and even GAE query cursors.
(http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/java/datastore/queriesandindexes.html#Query_Cursors)

public class EmployeePagingFilter implements org.springsource.????.FinderFilter {
public int firstResult;
public int maxResults;
public String cursorString;

public void filterQuery( Query q )

{ Cursor cursor = Cursor.fromWebSafeString(cursorString); q.setHint(JPACursorHelper.CURSOR_HINT, cursor); q.setFirstResult(firstResult); q.setMaxResults(maxResults); }

}

// Application initialises filter
EmployeePagingFilter filter = new EmployeePagingFilter();
filter.firstResult = 0;
filter.maxResults = 20;

// for each request, application updates the filter
filter.cursorString = cursorString;
findEmployeesByDepartment( dept, filter );

privileged aspect Employee_Roo_Finder {

public static Query Employee.findEmployeesByDepartment(String department, EmployeePagingFilter filter)

{ if (department == null || department.length() == 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("The department argument is required"); EntityManager em = Employee.entityManager(); Query q = em.createQuery("SELECT Employee FROM Employee AS employee WHERE employee.department = :department ORDER BY userName ASC"); q.setParameter("department", department); filter.filterQuery(q); return q; }

}

I just created ROO-3148 for specifying order by on standard find all methods (e.g. findAll<Entities>(), find<Entity>Entries() - not quite the same request, but very similar. Conceivably both improvements could be addressed at the same time with a common approach.
Hm, 95 votes are not enough...?
Is there any progress on this issue? It would be a huge help for my current project. Should I consider the fact that it is so low on the food chain that I will need to find another solution??

I made a proposal with a Pull Request on github here :
https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-roo/pull/56
I used these modifications with success here on some projects (tested with petclinic for example).
I think that can match to needs of some people here.
Thank you,
Vincent.
